Subject: URI delimiters and reserved characters (a [rest-discuss] public-service
 announcement)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=328589632; y=2pOCIg0w0jABxCy9EbLpRbJoaHJPXL1c4PRKlWwJvX2U51Nb1VU
X-Yahoo-Profile: etan_wexler

Alan Dean wrote (in
<http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/messag=
e/11189>):

> According to RFC3986 Section 2.2 [1] "[" and "]" are indeed c=
haracters
> reserved as general delimiters.

You are correct, sir. I was in=
correct to write that RFC 3986 prohibits
the square brackets. Rather, RFC 3=
986 permits the square brackets in
exactly one case: where the "host" subco=
mponent (of the "authority"
component) takes the form of an "IP-literal". W=
hen the "host"
subcomponent identifies a host by IPv6 address or an "IPvFut=
ure" token,
U+005B must appear as a prefix of the "host" component and U+00=
5D must
appear as a suffix of the host component.

> So is "/" [a general d=
elimiter]. That doesn't stop us using
> using "/". Why should it stop us us=
ing "[" or "]"?

The status of the square brackets as general delimiters is=
 not, per se,
what prevents the use of the square brackets where you want t=
hem.
Rather, it is simply impossible to produce a string with either square=

bracket appearing in the scheme, path, query, or fragment given the
gramma=
r G =3D (Sigma =3D {U+0000..U+007F}, N =3D {URI, scheme, hier-part,
query, =
fragment, authority, path-abempty, path-absolute, path-rootless,
path-empty=
, userinfo, host, port, IP-literal, IPvFuture, IPv6address,
h16, ls32, IPv4=
address, dec-octet, reg-name, segment, pchar, query,
fragment, pct-encoded,=
 unreserved, reserved, gen-delims, sub-delims}, P
=3D the set of production=
 rules enumerated in the ABNF of RFC 3986, S =3D
URI).

> Also, where in RF=
C3986 are "<" or ">" reserved? They aren't in section
> 2.2 and I have sear=
ch through the document for "<".

The less-than sign and greater-than sign =
are not reserved. They are
excluded. It is impossible to produce a string t=
hat contains either the
less-than sign or the greater-than sign given gramm=
ar G as above.

Frank Ellerman pushed repeatedly to have RFC 3986 account e=
xplicitly for
all characters in the ASCII repertoire. (Or something like th=
at, as I
don't remember the details and won't bother to trudge through the =
mail
archives.) Roy Fielding declined to do so. It's now up to the reader t=
o
use the process of elimination.

Rather than skimming or searching the en=
tirety of RFC 3986, focus just
on Appendix A, the collected ABNF
(<http://g=
biv.com/protocols/uri/rfc/rfc3986.html#collected-abnf>).

-- 
Please do not=
 include my address in public replies. I will read public
replies on the li=
st.
